channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-4727] container-create-child experiences long delay if mvn artefacts need to be downloaded from remote repository
item.description: Creating a child container on 6.2.1 can take a very long time if the profile to be applied to the child container references Maven artefacts that are not available locally. It takes about 5 mins for every remote bundle to be provisioned to the container. If there are multiple ( n ) bundles to be downloaded from remote repository, provisioning the child container takes n * 5 minutes.
item.summary: container-create-child experiences long delay if mvn artefacts need to be downloaded from remote repository

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Relevant logging in root container. Note the time difference between first and subsequent lines:

No unusual logging in child container apart from also showing the same 5 min delay.

Attaching thread dump of root (root.jstack) and child container (child.jstack) taken during the 5 mins wait period.

Child container shows this thread:

        at io.fabric8.maven.proxy.impl.MavenDownloadProxyServlet$2.run(MavenDownloadProxyServlet.java:160)

Another note: After the Maven artefact got finally downloaded and provisioned to the child container, it exists in the local Maven repo (~/.m2/repository) but not in data/maven/proxy/download:

fuse@172.17.0.2/16$ ll ~/.m2/repository/commons-dbcp/commons-dbcp/1.2/
 
commons-dbcp-1.2.jar       commons-dbcp-1.2.jar.sha1  _remote.repositories
 
 
 
fuse@172.17.0.2/16$ ll data/maven/proxy/
 
total 4
 
drwxrwxr-x 3 fuse fuse 4096 Dec 16 08:24 tmp
 
 
 
fuse@172.17.0.2/16$ ll data/maven/proxy/tmp/multipart/
 
total 0
 
 
 
fuse@172.17.0.2/16$ ll data/maven/upload/
 
total 0
Is there any other workaround to this bug than to download all these Maven artefacts to the local Maven repository (~/.m2/repository) in advance of creating the child container?

See this commit and its message
. The problem is ... Aether. Both root container and child container use the same local repository where artifact is downloaded. The chain of sequences is:

  • child → creates AetherSession with localRepository set → locks file in ~/.m2/repository → sends request to fabric-maven-proxy from root
  • root → receives request from child → creates AetherSession with localRepository set → locks file in ~/.m2/repository → sends request to external repo

The problem is that both set the same lock.

The workaround should be to define io.fabric8.maven.localRepository property in default profile as ${karaf.data}/repository

I confirm, suggested workaround resolves the problem for the time being.
Workaround was applied using this command:

profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.localRepository='${karaf.data}/repository' default

that was called prior to creating the child container.
Also captured in KCS article 2091691.

great to hear that!
Paolo Antinori do you remember why you suggested that I should revert this commit?
Paolo Antinori what do you think? I remember you wanted to leave default localRepository (== ~/.m2/repository) to make it better work on devs machines. Was there any other reason?
Grzegorz Grzybek no, the only reason I can recall was to not break local development workflows based using dev:watch command

Closing then.
So officially the workaround with setting localRepository should be used in root-child container scenario. This will however make dev:watch work differently (we should mvn install dev artifacts to different repository.

I know this JIRA is closed but want to get your opinion if its wise to enable the workaround by default in Fabric? I.e. have that property set out of the box.
Currently we need to often tell customers that they need to set this config in order to resolve the delays. Its very easy to forget about it as well.
Torsten Mielke, I'm working on fix in 6.3. This looks very promising - if everything's fine, I'll backport some settings and publish detailed "Maven usage guide for Fuse"

The problem was with this chain of actions:

  1. child requested root's fabric-maven-proxy for artifact
  2. child initiated aether session with localRepository set to ~/.m2/repository by default (aether locks created)
  3. root handled the requst
  4. root first checked io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.defaultRepositories first as aether's local repositories - this list was empty
  5. root then checked io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.repositories as aether's remote repositories - this time aether's session used localRepository set to ~/.m2/repository by default (aether locks attempted to be created - this time by root's process, but child already kept these locks)

The problem is that root's fabric-maven-proxy should first check if the artifact can't be served from local repository! So I've added FUSE_HOME/system as one of the local repositories checked before remote repositories

Fixed in 1.2.0.redhat-6-2-x-patch branch
Fixed in 1.2.0.redhat-6-3-x branch

Just to confirm, the comments suggest that we did not enable the workaround by default on any 6.2.1 patch but will have it enabled in 6.3 out of the box.
However the fix version is set to jboss-fuse-6.2-patches.

So is this workaround 

fabric:profile-edit --pid io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.localRepository='${karaf.data}/repository' default

needed on 6.2.1 latest patch R3 or R4 or not?

Here's git info:
The fix is: https://github.com/jboss-fuse/fabric8/commit/8144ed30e3361f3a2c3e808f1dba4195d9f1bee3

✔ ~/sources/github.com/jboss-fuse/fabric8-621xxx [1.2.0.redhat-6-2-x-patch|✔] 
13:48 $ git show 8144ed3
 
commit 8144ed30e3361f3a2c3e808f1dba4195d9f1bee3
 
Author: Kevin Earls <kevin@kevinearls.com>
 
Date:   Wed Jun 1 14:25:39 2016 +0200
 
 
 
    ENTESB-5478 add localRepository for io.fabric8.maven as workaround to prevent deadlocks downloading artifacts
 
    
    Conflicts:
 
        fabric/fabric8-karaf/src/main/resources/distro/fabric/import/fabric/profiles/default.profile/io.fabric8.maven.properties
 
 
 
diff --git a/fabric/fabric8-karaf/src/main/resources/distro/fabric/import/fabric/profiles/default.profile/io.fabric8.maven.properties b/fabric/fabric8-karaf/src/main/resources/distro/fabric/import/fabric/profiles/default.profile/io.fabric8.maven.properties
 
index 2f45053..9cd40c4 100644
 
--- a/fabric/fabric8-karaf/src/main/resources/distro/fabric/import/fabric/profiles/default.profile/io.fabric8.maven.properties
 
+++ b/fabric/fabric8-karaf/src/main/resources/distro/fabric/import/fabric/profiles/default.profile/io.fabric8.maven.properties
 
@@ -21,3 +21,7 @@ io.fabric8.maven.useFallbackRepositories = false
 
 io.fabric8.maven.repositories = ${profile:io.fabric8.agent/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.repositories}
 
 
 io.fabric8.maven.defaultRepositories = ${profile:io.fabric8.agent/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.defaultRepositories}
 
+
 
+io.fabric8.maven.localRepository = ${karaf.data}/repository
 
+
 
+
 
✔ ~/sources/github.com/jboss-fuse/fabric8-621xxx [1.2.0.redhat-6-2-x-patch|✔] 
13:48 $ git tag --contains 8144ed3
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621129
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621131
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621135
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621137
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621139
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621141
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621143
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621145
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621147
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621149
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621150
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621151
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621153
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621154
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621157
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621159
 
fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621161
So - the fix is in fabric8-1.2.0.redhat-621129 - I'm not sure which "R" it is.
Thanks, the fix will be in 6.2.1 R4 then.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
• Check your local Maven repo (~/.m2/repository). If it contains Maven artefact commons-dbcp/commons-dbcp/1.2, then delete it completely.
  • Start a fresh 6.2.1.
  • fabric:create --clean --profile fabric --wait-for-provisioning
  • profile-create test
  • profile-edit --bundle wrap:mvn:commons-dbcp/commons-dbcp/1.2 test
  • container-create-child --profile test root child
  • watch container-list - note the time it takes to fully provision the container. In this example it will take 5 mins. If you add other bundles to the test profile that are not available locally, it will take a multitude of 5 mins.
